art-style.name: Michael Avedon
art-style.title: Photographer
art-style.company: The grandson of master photographer Richard Avedon, he is currently a student at the International Center of Photography in New York City. He works primarily with black & white 35mm and medium format film.

art-style.name: Sam Falls
art-style.title: Artist
art-style.company: Falls uses photography, Photoshop, drawing, painting and sculpture to make artworks that combine abstract and figurative images. He has had solo shows in New York, Miami, Stockholm and Madrid and group exhibitions in more than a dozen cities including Brussels, London, Amsterdam and Philadelphia.

art-style.name: JR
art-style.title: Artist
art-style.company: A French conceptual artist who chooses to remain anonymous, JR hangs massive photos in public spaces, including giant pictures of eyes staring down from a Rio de Janeiro slum and portraits of Arabs and Jews hung all over Israel and the West Bank. He has shown at theTate Modern and the Centre Pompidou, and won a TED prize in 2011.

art-style.name: Jacob Kassay
art-style.title: Artist
art-style.company: Kassay's minimalist, mirror-like silver canvases have fetched as much as $290,500 at auction. He has had solo shows in Los Angeles, New York, Brussels and Paris, and his work is in museum collections including the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.

art-style.name: Pedro Lourenço
art-style.title: Fashion Designer
art-style.company: A much buzzed-about name among fashion insiders, Brazilian Lourenço showed his first ready-to-wear collection in Paris to critical acclaim when he was just 19. Born into a fashion family, both his mother and father are established designers in Sao Paulo--Lourenço is more than familiar with the inner workings of the rag trade. Recent collections have included aviator-inspired shirts, cropped pants and psychedelic print bomber jackets.

art-style.name: Toyin Odutola
art-style.title: Artist
art-style.company: Using ballpoint pens and other drawing utensils, Nigerian-born Odutola makes intricate portraits from photographs. She has had a one-woman show at the Jack Shainman gallery in New York City, and exhibited in group shows at the Menil Collection in Houston and at the Studio Museum in Harlem.

art-style.name: Ashley & Mary Kate Olsen
art-style.title: Fashion Designers
art-style.company: The Row, Elizabeth and James, Olsenboye, StyleMint

art-style.name: Adam Pendleton
art-style.title: Artist
art-style.company: Moving between painting, photography, and performance to create works that deal with race and language, Pendleton pairs seemingly unrelated concepts to force viewers to rethink the meaning of each. He has shown at the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney, the New Museum in New York City, and internationally, including at the once-every-three-year exhibition at the Palais de Tokyo in Paris.

art-style.name: Vladimir Roitfeld
art-style.title: Art Dealer
art-style.company: Raised in Paris, Roitfeld moved to L.A. at age 18 to study film at the University of Southern California. Disillusioned with Hollywood months after landing a job at Paramount, he hit Manhattan in early 2008 and teamed up with Australian heir Andy Valmorbida to stage exhibits in large venues off the beaten path, where the crowds and loud music wouldn't afflict the neighborhood. They split in 2011, though each continues to show. Roitfeld held a large sale at Sotheby's this fall.

art-style.name: Vito Schnabel
art-style.title: Art Dealer
art-style.company: Son of artist Julian Schnabel, he staged his first temporary art exhibition at age 16. He curates shows in various venues around the world and is known for matching artworks to a show's setting, using such varied locations as a cornfield in Long Island and a cloistered garden in Venice. Schnabel works with both established and emerging artists, including a show of performance artist Laurie Anderson's paintings.

art-style.name: Lucien Smith
art-style.title: Artist
art-style.company: Smith is a New York painter and sculptor who has shown at prestigious shows in New York, LA, Miami Basel, and London. He received a BFA in painting from the Cooper Union School of Art and frequently incorporates layered oil on canvas with bits of molding paste and detritus mixed in. Noted gallerist David Zwirner has named him as an artist to watch.

art-style.name: Artie Vierkant
art-style.title: Digital artist
art-style.company: Trained in photography, Vierkant makes one-of-a-kind abstract pieces suffused with light and bright colors, using Photoshop, a large-scale printer and pieces of layered plastic. He also works in video. He has had one-man shows in L.A., New York and Richmond, Va., and has participated in some 20 group shows, including in London, Berlin, Amsterdam and Glasgow.

education.name: Marisa Urrutia Gedney
education.title: Director of Operations and Programming, Echo Park

education.name: Nikhil Goyal
education.title: Author
education.company: Graduating high school in January, Goyal is the author of "One Size Does Not fit All: A Student's Assessment of School." His premise? That the U.S. education system does not serve every student--and that perhaps the "school of life" is the better place to learn.

energy.name: Trisha Andrew
energy.title: Organic Chemist
energy.company: 2011 L'Oreal USA For Women in Science Fellow

energy.name: Alexander Miller
energy.title: Assistant Professor
energy.company: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

food-wine.name: Grant Gordon
food-wine.title: Executive Chef
food-wine.company: Montrose Restaurant Associates; Gateway Restaurant Associates

food-wine.name: Jeff Mahin
food-wine.title: Chef
food-wine.company: Stella Rossa Pizza Bar, Do-Rite Donuts

games-apps.name: Matt Nava
games-apps.title: Concept Artist
games-apps.company: Otis College of Art and Design

hollywood.name: Aziz Ansari
hollywood.title: Actor, Writer
hollywood.company: Best known for his work on the NBC show "Parks and Recreation," Ansari also has a thriving movie career and a busy standup schedule. He recently took a page from the book of Louis C.K.by selling digital copies of his standup special "Dangerously Delicious" direct to fans for $5.

hollywood.name: Maude Apatow
hollywood.title: Actor, Writer
hollywood.company: Judd Apatow's daughter made her film debut in dad's 2007 "Knocked Up" as the daughter of a character played by her real-life mother, Leslie Mann. This year she revisted that role in the sort-of sequel, "This Is 40." Apatow has also become a well-followed tweeter and writer, contributing to Zooey Deschanel's website HelloGiggles.

hollywood.name: Jencarlos Canela
hollywood.title: Actor, Singer
hollywood.company: Canela is well-known on Spanish-language network Telemundo, where he's starred in four telenovelas including "Mas Sabe el Diablo" (“The Devil Knows Best”). But he's also a budding pop star. Canela sang the theme song for three of his TV shows. Telemundo featured his song "Suena" during its Olympic coverage. At least one of our judges believes Canela has a good chance to cross over.

hollywood.name: Sam Claflin
hollywood.title: Actor
hollywood.company: Claflin has had small roles in movies like "Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides" and "Snow White and the Huntsman." But Hollywood is expecting him to really breakout in next year's "Catching Fire," the second in "The Hunger Games" series. Claflin will play fan favorite Finnick Odair.

hollywood.name: Chris Colfer
hollywood.title: Actor, Writer
hollywood.company: Colfer is best known for playing Kurt Hummel on "Glee," but the young actor is quietly moving beyond TV. He wrote a best-selling children's book, "The Land of Stories,” and recently produced an independent movie,"Struck By Lightning." Colfer also wrote and stars in the film which will hit theaters in January.

hollywood.name: Lena Dunham
hollywood.title: Writer, Director, Actor
hollywood.company: Dunham's HBO show is a bona fide hit and whether she wants to be or not, she is now the voice of her generation. The writer/director/actress recently scored a $3.5 million advance for a book of essays. Season 2 of "Girls" starts in January.

hollywood.name: Greta Gerwig
hollywood.title: Actor, Writer
hollywood.company: Gerwig charmed Hollywood with her turn as Ben Stiller's love interest in the little-seen "Greenberg." Now she's writing her own material. Her latest, "Frances Ha," directed by boyfriend Noah Baumbach, was a huge hit at the recent New York Film Festival.

hollywood.name: Ariana Grande
hollywood.title: Actor
hollywood.company: For the past two and a half years, Grande has played second-fiddle to Victoria Justice on the Nickolodeon show "Victorious." Now she's getting her own spin-off show. Her character, Cat Valentine, is moving in with Sam Puckett from "iCarly" on the new show "Sam and Cat."

hollywood.name: Nicholas Hoult
hollywood.title: Actor
hollywood.company: Hoult made his acting debut in the 2001 movie "About A Boy" with Hugh Grant, but 2013 is looking like it will be Hoult's true breakout year. In February he'll star as a zombie in love (you read that right) in "Warm Bodies." Then in March he headlines Warner Bros.' take on the classic fairy tale "Jack the Giant Slayer."

hollywood.name: Max Landis
hollywood.title: Writer, Director
hollywood.company: Landis' debut film was last year's "Chronicle," a sort of found-footage movie about a group of Seattle teens who end up with superpowers. The dark film was a hit earning $127 million on a budget of $12 million. Now Landis has a chance to direct. "Me Him Her," which Landis also wrote, has been describe as "Reality Bites" on acid.

hollywood.name: Logan Lerman
hollywood.title: Actor
hollywood.company: Lerman was in line to be the next Daniel Radcliffe with "Percy Jackson." But the first film in the franchise didn't do quite as well as expected. Instead, Lerman is making his mark in smaller films like "The Perks of Being a Wallflower." He'll return to Percy Jackson next year in "Sea of Monsters."

hollywood.name: Chloe Moretz
hollywood.title: Actor
hollywood.company: Moretz is well on her way to becoming one of Hollywood's biggest stars. Only 15, she's shown she can hold her own in violent pictures like "Kick-Ass" and "Let Me In." Now she's taking on the iconic role of Carrie White in an update of the Stephen King horror classic. Expect to see Moretz on our Celebrity 100 in the next decade.

hollywood.name: Analeigh Tipton
hollywood.title: Actor
hollywood.company: Tipton has gone from coming in third on "America's Next Top Model" to one of Hollywood's hottest up and coming actresses in just four years. She stood out in last year's "Crazy, Stupid Love" as a babysitter with a crush on Steve Carrell. She'll next appear in "Warm Bodies," a zombie love story.

hollywood.name: Rebel Wilson
hollywood.title: Actress/Writer
hollywood.company: Ask anyone in Hollywood who the most promising young comedian is today and they'll tell you Rebel Wilson. The Australian actress stood out in a small role as Kristen Wiig's roommate in "Bridesmaids". Then she helped make the tiny "Pitch Perfect" a hit. Now she's hard at work on her first American sitcom, "Super Fun Night" which she wrote, produces and is starring in.

law-policy.name: Martha Bloem
law-policy.title: Senior Program Officer
law-policy.company: Scholar Rescue Fund, Institute of International Education

law-policy.name: Max Bruner
law-policy.title: Truman Scholar
law-policy.company: Center for Strategic and International Studies

law-policy.name: Ronan Farrow
law-policy.title: Rhodes Scholar
law-policy.company: Mia Farrow and Woody Allen's son was accepted to Yale Law at 16, advised State Department on youth affairs and is now a Rhodes Scholar.

law-policy.name: Andrew Kloster
law-policy.title: Fellow
law-policy.company: Foundation for Individual Rights in Education

law-policy.name: Nate Loewentheil
law-policy.title: Writer
law-policy.company: Founded the Roosevelt Campus Network while an undergraduate at Yale University. Now in his third year at Yale Law School, writes frequently for The New York Times and Politico, among others, and co-authored "Prosperity Economics: Building an Economy For All.”

marketing-advertising.name: Anthony Giordano
marketing-advertising.title: Director of Marketing and Business Development, North America

marketing-advertising.name: Maarten Peschier
marketing-advertising.title: Senior Technology Scientist, Emerging Media Lab

music.name: Wiz Khalifa
music.title: Musician
music.company: Gallery: 30 Under 30: Music

music.name: Adele
music.title: Musician
music.company: If the recorded music industry is dying, the big-voiced Brit didn't get the memo: her album 21 has sold over 23 million copies worldwide.

music.name: Avicii
music.title: Musician
music.company: The young Swede picked up a Grammy nomination -- and, thanks to six-figure fees for live shows, a spot on FORBES' inaugural top-earning DJs list.

music.name: Justin Bieber
music.title: Musician
music.company: The Canadian crooner released his third album, launched a new world tour and continued investing in startups on his way to a $55 million payday this year, earning him a spot on the cover of FORBES in June.

music.name: Benny Blanco
music.title: Producer
music.company: With production and songwriting credits on smash singles like Maroon 5's "Payphone" and Rihanna's "Diamonds," Blanco is quickly becoming an industry powerhouse.

music.name: Drake
music.title: Musician
music.company: The former Degrassi star earned $20 million last year, buoyed by live shows, a new album and endorsements with the likes of Sprite and Kodak.

music.name: Daniel Ek
music.title: Cofounder
music.company: Spotify

music.name: Lady Gaga
music.title: Musician
music.company: Though she's been making fewer headlines of late, Gaga continues to rake in cash from music sales, touring and new fragrance Fame.

music.name: Skylar Grey
music.title: Musician
music.company: The singer-songwriter wrote the hook to Eminem and Rihanna's "Love The Way You Lie," which earned five Grammy nominations; she's set for her major label solo debut in 2013.

music.name: Calvin Harris
music.title: Musician
music.company: The Scottish DJ has successfully crossed over into the pop world with hits like his Rihanna collaboration "We Found Love," adding to his coffers with healthy profits on the road.

music.name: Matt Jones
music.title: Cofounder
music.company: CrowdSurge

music.name: Ke$ha
music.title: Musician
music.company: Take some glitter, a bit of dirt, mix in some catchy pop hooks and you get Ke$ha, the hard-partying embodiment of a generation. Smash single "Die Young" should keep her star rising.

music.name: Adam Kluger
music.title: Founder
music.company: The Kluger Agency

music.name: Kendrick Lamar
music.title: Musician
music.company: Dr. Dre's newest protege appears set for stardom with the launch of album Good Kid, M.A.A.D City, which debuted with sales of 242,000 its opening week.

music.name: Bruno Mars
music.title: Musician
music.company: He may not be a billionaire, but the pop singer-songwriter now grosses a quarter of a million dollars a night on the road -- and he did get his picture in FORBES.

music.name: Mac Miller
music.title: Musician
music.company: The Pittsburgh native followed local pal Wiz Khalifa to hip-hop stardom, earning a spot as the featured artist on last year's 30 Under 30 -- and $6.5 million.

music.name: Marcus Mumford
music.title: Musician
music.company: Folksy frontman and his indie rock act Mumford & Sons shocked the world by selling over 600,000 copies of their new album, Babel, in its opening week -- the second-best debut of the year.

music.name: Frank Ocean
music.title: Musician
music.company: Buoyed by the success of hip-hop collective Odd Future, Ocean has established himself as a solo act, earning six Grammy nominations this year, tied for the most of any artist.

music.name: Katy Perry
music.title: Musician
music.company: This "California Gurl" joined Michael Jackson as the only artist to have five No. 1 singles from the same album; she continues to pad her coffers with touring, endorsements and a biopic.

music.name: Rihanna
music.title: Musician
music.company: The Barbados-born diva has parlayed pop hits into endorsements with Vita Coco and Nivea, fragrance Reb'l Fleur and sold-out shows around the world.

music.name: James "J" Sider
music.title: Founder
music.company: BandPage

music.name: Skrillex
music.title: Musician
music.company: The side-mulletted DJ brought dubstep music to the mainstream. Now he earns six figures for live performances and makes music for movies like Wreck-It Ralph.

music.name: Taylor Swift
music.title: Musician
music.company: New album Red moved 1.2 million units its opening week, the best debut since 2002. Swift also earns big from endorsements with the likes of CoverGirl and grosses over $1 million for live shows.

music.name: Alex White
music.title: Cofounder
music.company: The Next Big Sound

music.name: Sara Winter
music.title: Director of Tour Marketing
music.company: AEG Live/Messina Group

science-healthcare.name: Cindy Chang
science-healthcare.title: Medical Student
science-healthcare.company: Cleveland Clinic Lerner College of Medicine

science-healthcare.name: Pierce Graham-Jones
science-healthcare.title: West Health Innovator-in-Residence
science-healthcare.company: Department of Health and Human Services

science-healthcare.name: Jillian Shapiro
science-healthcare.title: Graduate Student
science-healthcare.company: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

sports.name: Usain Bolt
sports.title: Sprinter
sports.company: The six-time Olympic gold medalist has been dubbed the "World's Most Marketable Athlete" by the website SportsPromedia.com, which notes that he "brings the promise of something historic with every appearance." Bolt's $9 million a year deal with Puma is the biggest ever for a track & field athlete.
